messages.message:
People in parts of Japan are being told to evacuate, with some homes losing power on Friday as Typhoon Ampil approaches the coast near Tokyo.
As of early Friday local time, the storm was recording winds of 185 kilometers per hour (115 miles per hour), according to the latest advisory from the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC).
It could strengthen further in the next 12 hours, with the storm reaching peak intensity as it passes by Japan.
The storm’s center is expected to remain slightly offshore as it turns toward the northeast and moves away from Japan, according to the JTWC and Japan’s Meteorological Agency.
If it stays offshore and only brushes the coast, it might only have a light impact on Japan, bringing rain and wind to some areas including Tokyo.

Residents in parts of Japan are being ordered to evacuate with some homes losing power on Friday as Typhoon Ampil approaches the coast near Tokyo, CNN reported.
The storm is expected to continue intensifying in the next 12 hours, potentially reaching its peak as it passes near Japan.
The storm is forecasted to hit the area by late Friday, bringing strong winds and heavy rain.
Further, a similar notice was issued in the city of Yokohama, south of Tokyo, with authorities warning that all residents should be prepared to evacuate.
If it stays offshore and only brushes the coast, it might only have a light impact on Japan, bringing rain and wind to some areas including Tokyo.

A hurricane warning was in effect for Bermuda with Ernesto expected to pass near or over the island Saturday.
“All of the guidance show this system as a large hurricane near Bermuda,” said the National Hurricane Centre in Miami.
Ernesto is expected to pass near or east of Atlantic Canada on Monday.
On Thursday, the storm was generating southern winds in Puerto Rico, which have a heating effect as opposed to the typical cooling trade winds that blow from the east.
More than 290,000 people remained in the dark on Thursday evening after Ernesto swiped past Puerto Rico late on Tuesday as a tropical storm before strengthening into a hurricane.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (AP) — Hurricane Ernesto strengthened into a Category 2 storm Thursday night as it barreled toward Bermuda after leaving hundreds of thousands of people in Puerto Rico without power or water.
A hurricane warning was in effect for Bermuda, with Ernesto expected to pass near or over the island Saturday.
“All of the guidance show this system as a large hurricane near Bermuda,” said the National Hurricane Center in Miami.
Crews have flown more than 540 miles (870 kilometers) across Puerto Rico and identified 400 power line failures, with 150 of them already fixed, said Juan Saca, president of Luma Energy, a private company that operates the transmission and distribution of power in Puerto Rico.
At least 250,000 customers across Puerto Rico also were without water given the power outages, down from a maximum of 350,000.

A hurricane warning was in effect for Bermuda, with Ernesto expected to pass near or over the island Saturday.
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (AP) — Hurricane Ernesto strengthened into a Category 2 storm Thursday night as it barreled toward Bermuda after leaving hundreds of thousands of people in Puerto Rico without power or water.
“All of the guidance show this system as a large hurricane near Bermuda,” said the National Hurricane Center in Miami.
Crews have flown more than 540 miles (870 kilometers) across Puerto Rico and identified 400 power line failures, with 150 of them already fixed, said Juan Saca, president of Luma Energy, a private company that operates the transmission and distribution of power in Puerto Rico.
At least 250,000 customers across Puerto Rico also were without water given the power outages, down from a maximum of 350,000.

Hurricane Ernesto strengthened into a Category 2 storm Thursday night as it barreled toward Bermuda after leaving hundreds of thousands of people in Puerto Rico without power or water.
A hurricane warning was in effect for Bermuda, with Ernesto expected to pass near or over the island Saturday.
“All of the guidance show this system as a large hurricane near Bermuda,” said the National Hurricane Center in Miami.
More than 290,000 of 1.4 million customers remained in the dark Thursday evening, more than a day after Ernesto swiped past Puerto Rico late Tuesday as a tropical storm before strengthening into a hurricane.
At least 250,000 customers across Puerto Rico also were without water given the power outages, down from a maximum of 350,000.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico—Hurricane Ernesto barreled toward Bermuda on Thursday after leaving hundreds of thousands of people in Puerto Rico without power or water as sweltering heat enveloped the U.S. territory, raising concerns about people’s health.
A hurricane warning was in effect for Bermuda, with Ernesto expected to pass near or over the island on Saturday.
“All of the guidance show this system as a large hurricane near Bermuda,” said the National Hurricane Center in Miami.
Crews have flown more than 540 miles (870 kilometers) across Puerto Rico and identified 400 power line failures, with 150 of them already fixed, said Juan Saca, president of Luma Energy, a private company that operates the transmission and distribution of power in Puerto Rico.
At least 250,000 customers across Puerto Rico also were without water given the power outages, down from a maximum of 350,000.

Ernesto grows into a Category 2 hurricane as it aims for Bermudatoggle caption Alejandro Granadillo/APSAN JUAN, Puerto Rico — Hurricane Ernesto strengthened into a Category 2 storm Thursday night as it barreled toward Bermuda after leaving hundreds of thousands of people in Puerto Rico without power or water.
A hurricane warning was in effect for Bermuda, with Ernesto expected to pass near or over the island Saturday.
The storm was centered about 410 miles (660 kilometers) south-southwest of Bermuda late Thursday.
“All of the guidance show this system as a large hurricane near Bermuda,” said the National Hurricane Center in Miami.
At least 250,000 customers across Puerto Rico also were without water given the power outages, down from a maximum of 350,000.

Beryl is making its way to the Caribbean Sea after brewing in the Atlantic OceanArticle first published: Monday, July 01, 2024, 5 a.m.
Beryl, developed in the Atlantic Ocean, is now shifting toward the Caribbean Sea.
Category 5 Hurricane Beryl is 445 miles east-southeast of Isla Beata Dominican Republic and 775 miles east-southeast of Kingston Jamaica, with maximum sustained wind of 165 mph.
A Tropical Storm Warning means that tropical storm conditions are expected somewhere within the warning area within 36 hours.
RAINFALL: Hurricane Beryl is expected to produce rainfall totals of 4 to 8 inches, with localized maxima of 12 inches, in portions of Jamaica on Wednesday.

Beryl developed in the Atlantic Ocean and is shifting toward the Caribbean SeaArticle first published: Monday, July 01, 2024, 5 a.m.
Category 5 Hurricane Beryl's journey: it developed in the Atlantic Ocean, made its way to the Caribbean Sea.
"Additional weakening is expected thereafter, though Beryl is forecast to remain a hurricane in the northwestern Caribbean."
A Tropical Storm Warning means that tropical storm conditions are expected somewhere within the warning area within 36 hours.
RAINFALL: Hurricane Beryl is expected to produce rainfall totals of 4 to 8 inches, with localized maxima of 12 inches, in portions of Jamaica on Wednesday.

Hurricane Ernesto is due to bring life-threatening floods, storm surges and 100 mph winds to Bermuda, with dangerous conditions likely to start Friday ahead of the storm's likely arrival on the island in the next 24 hours, forecasters said.
The whole island is under a hurricane warning and as much as 15 inches of rain is expected.
Hurricane-strength winds, which are least 74 mph, are expected to extend 70 miles from the storm's center, while tropical storm-force winds of at least 39 mph will be felt 265 miles away.
"A dangerous storm surge is expected to produce significant coastal flooding on Bermuda in areas of onshore winds.
A satellite image shows Hurricane Ernesto approaching Bermuda.

Hurricane Ernesto is set to bring life-threatening flooding, storm surges and winds of up to 100 mph to Bermuda, forecasters said, with dangerous conditions beginning Friday before the storm hits the island in the next 24 hours.
The Category 2 storm is 255 miles southwest of the North Atlantic island and moving at 13 mph, the National Hurricane Center said in an 8 a.m. update.
A hurricane warning has been issued for the entire island and up to 15 inches of rain is expected.
Hurricane-force winds of at least 74 mph are expected Extend 70 miles from the storm’s center, while tropical storm force winds of at least 39 mph can be felt 265 miles away.
Satellite image shows Hurricane Ernesto approaching Bermuda.

messages.message:
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (AP) — Hurricane Ernesto charged toward Bermuda on Friday as officials on the tiny island in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean prepared to open shelters and close government offices.
Tropical storm conditions including strong winds and life-threatening floods were expected to start affecting Bermuda on Friday afternoon, according to the National Hurricane Center.
A surfer prepares to enter the water before the passage of Tropical Storm Ernesto at La Pared beach in Luquillo, Puerto Rico, Tuesday, Aug. 13, 2024.
La Plata river floods a road after Tropical Storm Ernesto passed through Toa Baja, Puerto Rico, Wednesday, Aug. 14, 2024.
La Plata river floods a road after Tropical Storm Ernesto passed through Toa Baja, Puerto Rico, Wednesday, Aug. 14, 2024.

Hurricane Ernesto barrels toward Bermuda as wealthy British territory prepares for the stormSAN JUAN, Puerto Rico -- Hurricane Ernesto charged toward Bermuda on Friday as officials on the tiny island in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean prepared to open shelters and close government offices.
The Category 2 storm was located 255 miles (415 kilometers) south-southwest of Bermuda.
Tropical storm conditions including strong winds and life-threatening floods were expected to start affecting Bermuda on Friday afternoon, according to the National Hurricane Center.
In preparation for the storm, officials in the wealthy British territory announced they would suspend public transportation and close the airport by Friday night.
Ernesto is the fifth named storm and the third hurricane of this year's Atlantic hurricane season.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (AP) — Hurricane Ernesto charged toward Bermuda on Friday as officials in the tiny British territory in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean prepared to open shelters and close government offices.
The Category 2 storm located 180 miles (285 kilometers) south-southwest of Bermuda was packing maximum sustained winds of 100 mph (155 kph).
Tropical storm conditions including strong winds and life-threatening floods were expected to start affecting Bermuda on Friday afternoon, according to the National Hurricane Center.
In preparation for the storm, officials in the wealthy British territory announced they would suspend public transportation and close the airport by Friday night.
Ernesto is the fifth named storm and the third hurricane of this year’s Atlantic hurricane season.

(NOAA via AP)SAN JUAN – Hurricane Ernesto charged toward Bermuda on Friday as officials in the tiny British territory in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean prepared to open shelters and close government offices.
The Category 2 storm located 180 miles (285 kilometers) south-southwest of Bermuda was packing maximum sustained winds of 100 mph (155 kph).
Tropical storm conditions including strong winds and life-threatening floods were expected to start affecting Bermuda on Friday afternoon, according to the National Hurricane Center.
“Hurricane Ernesto seriously threatens our community,” he said.
Ernesto is the fifth named storm and the third hurricane of this year’s Atlantic hurricane season.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (AP) — Hurricane Ernesto charged toward Bermuda on Friday as officials in the tiny British territory in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean prepared to open shelters and close government offices.
The Category 2 storm located 180 miles (285 kilometres) south-southwest of Bermuda was packing maximum sustained winds of 100 mph (155 kph).
Tropical storm conditions including strong winds and life-threatening floods were expected to start affecting Bermuda on Friday afternoon, according to the National Hurricane Center.
In preparation for the storm, officials in the wealthy British territory announced they would suspend public transportation and close the airport by Friday night.
Ernesto is the fifth named storm and the third hurricane of this year's Atlantic hurricane season.

Tropical storm conditions — including strong winds and life-threatening floods — began on Friday and are expected to continue through Saturday night, according to the National Hurricane Center.
La Plata river overflows onto a road after Tropical Storm Ernesto passed through Toa Baja, Puerto Rico, Wednesday, Aug. 14, 2024.

Tropical storm conditions — including strong winds and life-threatening floods — began on Friday and are expected to continue through Saturday night, according to the National Hurricane Center.
In preparation for the storm, officials in the wealthy British territory announced they would suspend public transportation and close the airport by Friday night.
Ernesto is the fifth named storm and the third hurricane of this year’s Atlantic hurricane season.
The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration has predicted an above-average Atlantic hurricane season this year because of record warm ocean temperatures.

TOKYO: Typhoon Ampil edged closer to Japan’s main island of Honshu on Friday (Aug 16), forcing major Japanese airlines to cancel flights and the government to issue a warning against possible landslides and flooding.
Japan Airlines and All Nippon Airways cancelled some 90 international flights, impacting more than 15,000 passengers.
The latest typhoon, categorised as a severe tropical storm, will be at its closest around midday on Aug 16, according to weather forecasters.
Korean Air Lines said 12 of its flights between Japan and South Korea will be suspended on Aug 16 and 17.
Cathay Pacific Airways said that its Japan flights are currently operating normally, adding that it is “closely monitoring the potential impact of severe tropical storm Ampil”.
